channel.title: Fluid Mechanics
channel.generator: Webpage HTML Export plugin for Obsidian

item.title: Boiling
item.description:
We were lied to
Water boils at 100 C here on Earth. It is converted from liquid to steam, characterized by bubbling. This is not the only phenomenon that converts water to steam, evaporation also does the same. Evaporation happens at just about any temperature of the liquid, unlike boiling, which happens only at one point. We were all taught this at school. Reality, however, is a little more complex and boiling is not nearly as absolute as they'd like us to believe.
To illustrate this, lets take an example. Imagine a closed vessel with liquid water and air. The vessel is initially at

item.title: Bulk Polymerization
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers
Simple - uses monomer and monomer soluble initiator. The monomer is where the reactions occur for polymerization, not in any other medium
This is good for high purity, high molar mass products, good for polycondensation. Polyaddition is better suited for Solution Polymerization, its also good for polycondensation
Issues with bulk polymerization are with heat transfer (if heat is generated, it's difficult to remove and causes autoacceleration) and viscosity buildup. These are solved by only allowing low conversion.
Polystyrene is an example of a polymer made using bulk polymerization
Advantages

High yield per reactor volume
Easy Polymer Recovery
The option of casting the polymerization mixture into final product form
Limitations:
Difficulty in removing last traces of monomer
The problem of dissipating heat produced during the reaction. This can be improved by providing special baffles
The problem of viscosity buildup in the reactor

item.title: Emulsion Polymerization
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers
This has one basic difference to Suspension Polymerization, the initiator is soluble in the solvent, and its insoluble in the monomer
Particles of size 0.1 to 1 micrometer
Because molecular weight distribution is better

Anionic surfactants (?) are used at 1-5 wt% of the monomer. they have hydrophobic hydrocarbon molecules on one end and a hydrophillic anionic head group. These surfactant molecules, when dissolved in water, above their "critical micelle concentration", begin associating into groups of spherical aggregates called micelles, which contain about 100 molecules.
These micelles contain a hydrophobic core, which can absorb a good amount of water insoluble substances
When monomer is added, 3 phases develop - aqueous phase with small amounts of monomer and surfactant, large droplets containing lots of monomer and surfactant, small droplets (very very common) containing some monomer and surfactant around


This is the stage where particles are formed. What are particles? The book doesn't say - I guess they are drops but polymer. Particle nucleation occurs through three methods:

Micellular Nucleation - Micelle receives oligomeric radical formed from initiator and monomer in aqueous phase. Micelle keeps growing and attracting more monomer until no more micelles left without radical.
Homogeneous nucleation - chain radical formed, attracted surfactant for colloidal stability and monomers for propagation. Ends when these particles get big enough to attract even oligomeric radicals
Coagulation nucleation - A bunch of oligomeric radicals clump up together until the molecule is big enough to achieve colloidal stability itself and then starts absorbing monomer and propagates
Micellular nucleation happens when the solution is well above CMC, homogeneous is when surfactant is little and coagulation is when surfactant is even less

in the first part of particle growth (AKA interval 2), monomers are provided by monomer droplets to the particles, to keep them propagating. When all the monomer droplets are used up, we enter interval 3, when rate of polymerization continuously decreases


Taking Smith Ewart's Case 2, each particle can be assumed to have only one radical at a time and when another enters, the two react extremely fast to terminate. This way, each particle has, on average one radical, half the time:


Formation of core shell structures, Good for the environment, widely used in industry
Contamination by inorganic salts and dispersion stabilizers is the biggest problem

Developed with the objective of controlling number of particles. A miniemulsion is formed with droplets large in number and size to capture all radicals in the solution. The number of droplets are the number of particles
Danger What? how is this different from regular emulsion polymerization? weirdddd

item.title: Equation of motion
item.description:
#fluidmech
#fluidmech
Warning This will be tricky


On a solid fluid boundary, fluid layers adjacent to the solid move with the same velocity as the solid - This is the no slip condition
For liquid gas interface, the shear stress is negligible.
For liquid liquid interface, the shear stress is continuous over the interface. The momentum flux is perpendicular to the interface


Equation of continuity is mass rate balance and equation of motion is a momentum rate balance Try and understand the equation of motion
The diagram, while I cannot draw right now, is very similar to the equation of continuity
the things moving through are the momenum fluxes
There are two types of stresses, conductive (viscous) stress and convective stress
Equation of motion is developed by writing a momentum balance over a volume element fixed in space, through which a fluid is flowing

x component is developed as follows, convective and molecular transport (conductive)
Rate at which x momentum enters and leaves the faces at x and x+ are (convective)
Rate at which x momentum enters and leaves the faces at Y and Y+ are (Conductive)
Rate at which x momentum enters and leaves the faces at Z and Z+ are (Conductive)
Addition of the above 3 components gives the net rate of addition of x momentum.



Rate at which Y momentum enters and leaves the faces at x and x+ are (convective)
Rate at which Y momentum enters and leaves the faces at Y and Y+ are (Conductive)
Rate at which Y momentum enters and leaves the faces at Z and Z+ are (Conductive)

you know how to do this


Net rate of addition of X-momentum is:

In addition there is an external force (typically the gravitation) acting on the fluid in volume element. X component of this force is (mass * g_x basically lol). The g_x is the g in the x direction, which is 0 na lmao
Total of the above 4 terms gives x-component only, and should be equal to the rate of accumulation of x-momentum within the volume element

This gives:
dividing both sides by the control volume:

similarly can be written for y and z elements
phi actually contains both convective and molecular transport elements

This course is an industrially relevant course which help students to understand various components of fluid
transport systems used in industry such as pipes, fittings, valves, pumps, blowers, compressors, vacuum
pumps etc. The industrial operations involve heating, cooling of the reactors and other mixing/separation
equipment which is provided by steam boilers, thermic fluid heaters, chillers, cooling towers etc. Many
reactions and separation equipment also require understanding of fluid flow at design, operation and
troubleshooting stage.

Bernoulli's Equation
Utility Network - anything that isn't part of a process is utility, like chilled water, heating water, steam and nitrogen. Nitrogen is inert (relatively). Brines to reduce freezing point without corroding the machinery
Fluid Moving Machinery - pumps, vacuum systems, etc
Equation of motion

item.title: Polymers
item.description:
#polymers
Tip These are my notes from Introduction to Polymers, Robert J. Young and college classes
#polymers
Quote “So once you do know what the question actually is, you'll know what the answer means.”

SYllabus for midems:

classification of polymers
DIfferent mixing techniques - dry blending
Extrusion techniques - basic twin screw and single screw
A polymer is a substance composed of long sequences of one or more species of atoms or groups of aton of polymers

DIfferent mixing techniques - dry blending
Extrusion techniques - basic twin screw and single screw
ms linked together by primary, usually covalent bonds
n of polymers

DIfferent mixing techniques - dry blending
Extrusion techniques - basic twin screw and single screw
Usually two plastics are mixed to make blends to make one with exactly the properties one wants
PET - poly(ethylene terepthalate) is a blend of PE and PT

blends differ from composites in the sense that composites have one material that is reinforcing mechanically
both blends and composites are binary phase mix
Danger The history is NOT IN THE SYLLABUS (i think)


1820 -> This guy, Thomas Hancock, found a way to blend additives to rubber (a natural polymer) by beating it up (masticating it)
1839 -> Charles Goodyear added sulphur to rubber and found it got stronger. This process was named vulcanization.
1846 - 1870 -> Some guy prepared nitrocellulose, sold it as an explosive. Another guy thought to mold it and make items out of it as it was found it be a hard elastic material that is also soluble and easily mold-able. Two other guys thought it would be smart to do this with something that isn't an explosive - celluloid. Instant commercial success.
1892 -> Cross, Bevan and Beadle patented the viscose process for dissolving and regenerating cellulose
1920s -> This absolute chad of a human, Hermann Staudinger studied the synthesis, structure and properties of polyoxymethylene and polystyrene to give emprical evidence of his idea that polymers are really just macromolecules containing large sequences of monomers. Everyone doubted him, but the haters were proven wrong


Types of polymers
Molar Mass
Polymerization
Processing
Industry - not in syllabus
Properties of Polymers

item.title: Properties of Polymers
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers

Polymers are always covalently bonded
With high inductive effect, low molar mass molecules are liberated as the electronegative group abstracts hydrogen from the carbon
Primary bonding - covalent and ionic
Secondary - Configuration and conformation
Configuration - you cant change this without breaking the bonds
Conformation - this is related to the rotation of the bonds
Tacticity - relating to the stereochemistry of repeating units
Tacticity - isotacticity, atacticity and syndiostereotacticity

The above is isotactic
Glass transition temperature - when you heat the polymer, there is a transition phase, called glass transition. Mostly polymers are semicrystalline or amorphous - glass transition is when the polymer is in amorphous state. The lower this temperature, the more flexible the polymer is. Used in thermoplastic. Above , polymer is flexible and below it it is glassy. is the temperature below which the polymer is mostly rigid
Tg causes a second order phase change

The is the temperature when the specific volume vs temperature graph has a change in slope
DSC - differential scanning calorimetry, can find the , , , gel point, everything
DMTA - dynamic mechanical and thermal analysis
DSC and DMTA are two techniques to get the value
Melting temperature - Used in thermoplastic.
Melting temperature - related to heat gain
Crystallization temperature, - Used in thermoplastic. When you cool the polymer it starts crystallizing. When the entropy change is the highest - peak crystallization temperature
Semi crystalline polymer shows , and . Amorphous only shows
Semi Crystalline polymers is defined by how regular the packing of the polymer is.
Amorphous Polymers have a completely irregular packing
Gel point - Used in thermoset. When the degree of polymerization of a thermoset tends to infinity
Curing temperature - Used in thermoset. When the polymer cures

in conformation you have gauch, trans and eclipsed
isotactic means that if it's arranged in a regular pattern
in polymerization there are three types of configuration - cis or trans - cis will give better machanical properties - also called diene polymerization, strereoregularity - tacticity, configuration based on structure - head to head, tail to tail or head to tail
head to head and tail to tail dont occur much, mostly head to tail


Tg more flexible above. Dis be'eth a mechanical property


In case of polymers, there are two types of crystals - lamella, and spherulites
Lamella - forms around the nucleation point, the chain folds
The many lamella form spherulite, spherulites are big spherical crystals
If the rate of cooling is high, crystals arent formed well. Slow rate of cooling forms good polymers



dialatency - shear thickening
Shear thinning - pseudoplasticity

item.title: Radical Polymerization
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers
-All these notes are derived from intro to polymerization, I don't hide this fact, it's the truth-

If step growth was about simple reactions occurring between monomers and polymers to grow the chain, radical polymerization is about the propagation of a free radical end which keeps growing it.
It's used for unsaturated monomers

Radical polymerization undergoes several chemical reactions that determine the end polymers' structures. These reactions include:

Radical Polymerization Initiation - Specific chemicals that generate free radicals, which react with monomers that cause free radical polymer chains
Radical Polymerization Propagation - How the free radical polymer chains keep growing
Radical Polymerization Termination - How the free radical polymer chains lose their free radicals and become "dead chains"
Radical Polymerization Chain Transfer - Where the free radical area gets transferred to a different chain

A lot of this has been covered in the previous section, I'm just developing it here - getting it all together


Using kinetics analysis, without taking into account chain transfer:

Using kinetics analysis, taking into account chain transfer to get the Mayo Walling Equation


At different conversions, the diffusive properties of the chains differ (lol). This is important because these diffusive properties, control how molecules meet each other and react. Thus if they are low enough in any area they can cause certain parts of the radical polymerization mechanism to go slower or faster. Certain parts can be "diffusion controlled"
Types of diffusion

Segmental Diffusion - Refers to orientation of molecules reacting. Propagation and termination are controlled by this at low conversions since they molecules have to be in correct orientation to react and translational diffusion when the chain is small is good
Translational Diffusion - Refers to actual diffusion (the centre of mass moves). Controls the termination step at high conversions. An interesting effect, known as autoacceleration or the Trommsdorf-Norrish effect occurs when reaction mixtures become translational diffusion controlled - the termination step decreases and since propagation is not affected by translational diffusion (monomers still diffuse about easily), the conversion increases and the termination step decreases more, so on and so on. The reaction mixture becomes really viscous and even glass like (vitrifies)
Reactive diffusion - everything slow, chains move only by adding new monomers

Molar Mass Distribution - when I finally make this page, I'm including this there

Situation is different for combination and Mn/Mw ends up being (2+B)/2

Let some things be mysteries. Why spoil the magic of not knowing the dirty reality of how these constants are found out?

I'm not going into the details - they used the arrhenius equation and they found the dependence of the rate ofndex.html polymerization and thus degree of polymerization with temperature



Ceiling temperature - the temperature at with propagation stops due to the reaction becoming non spontaneous. There's an equation for this, I'll add it later, when they teach us this stuff probably


Bulk Polymerization - Homogeneous polymerization process
Solution Polymerization - homogeneous polymerization process
Suspension Polymerization - Heterogeneous Polymerization Process
Emulsion Polymerization - Heterogeneous Polymerization Process

Chain polymerizations where termination reactions are very very small in number are called living polymerizations as they dont get dead chains.
We come real close to that in Radical polymerization using two separate techniques - rapid capping and uncapping of active sites and exchange of caps between radical chains to prevent their reactions and thus termination

This is an application of the first technique using nitroxide to cap and uncap active sites real quick. This suffers from issues such as side reactions causing disproportionation in the chain radical with nitroxide

You also got stuff like TEMPO, TIPNO and SG1, which are better than nitroxide in many ways
The kinetics of these kind of reactions shouldn't be covered by bozos like me, read the book for this. Sorry


I'll write this part on a reread



Section for stuff I don't understand and maybe reddit questions I end up posting

Other than rapid end capping and uncapping, how can termination be reduced? I don't suppose they use reversible deactivation radical polymerization in industry - so how do they control degree of polymerization?
In emulsion polymerization are the monomers soluble in water? If not, then how are small quantities of monomer dissolved in the aqueous phase?How is micellar nucleation even possible?


calculate half life of benzoyl peroxide in benzene as an initiator with rate constant 8 * 10^(-6)


Question 4.2 in the book introduction to polymer science

Part B is so similar to part A that it's a waste of my time to cover it



I'm guessing the propagation and initiation and thus termination also includes a chain formed from the non side of styrene having the radical so this above reaction scheme is not complete and also I'm not sure what I have here is a reaction scheme - what is a reaction scheme??




All seem to be simple formula application so I'm NOT doing :/

item.title: Solution Polymerization
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers
Monomer and initiator are placed in a solvent, where they react
Solves the heat transfer and viscosity issue with Bulk Polymerization but causes new issues like chain transfer to solvent.
To isolate the polymer from the solvent, we either evaporate it off and if the polymer is insoluble in the solvent, we precipitate it off. Both these processes are inefficient and aren't used widely in industry
Prof's PPT

Heat removed during polymerization can be facilitated by conducting the polymerization in an organic solvent or water
Both the initiator and the monomer must be soluble in it
the solvent must have acceptable chain transfer characteristics and suitable melting and boiling points for the conditions of the polymerization and subsequent solvent removal step
Solvent choice may be influences by other factors such as flash point, cost and toxicity
Reactors are usually stainless steel or glass lined

item.title: Suspension Polymerization
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers
Better than solution polymerization. This requires the monomer and initiator to be insoluble in the solvent. The monomer and initiator are added, a suspension(whats the difference between a suspension and an emulsion?) is created, this is agitated at high speeds to create small droplets in which the polymerization reactions are taken into completion. After its complete, the polymer is filtered or centrifuged out. Dispersion stabilizers are also used (what are dispersion stabilizers? How do they work?)
This is great because the heat transfer surface is amazing, viscosity doesn't matter too much, widely used in industry.
According to sir, the only process that gives beads (not powder, much more than 10 micrometer), is suspension. So in exam write this
particles of size 10-1000 micrometer
1500 RPM

item.title: Water Water Everywhere
item.description:
Water water everywhere
It's all up in my underwear
But it didn't come from out
My rectum had but a nasty shout
I have some bad news to share
The smell of poop you'll have to bear
Excrement flowing down my pants
Like a marching row of ants
You would do well, to be aware
Of my folly, my shame to bear
for last night i had taco bell
And now I'm on my way to hell
Oh! My bowels scream and shout
Please do let the feces out
I say nay, you shall not pass!
I'm feeling gay, it's up my arse ;)
But the flavours burn and sear
as the horrors leave my rear
I should have listened, I should have heard
My mother when she gave me curd
The wet flow of my diarrhoea
giving me hypothermia
for my underpants are soaked
and the AC is so cold!
In front of me, is straight brown hair
smells like flowers and all things fair
the girl I like, so unaware
of the smell behind her chair
For 3 years, 2 months and 15 days
I've tried so hard, that she just may
look upon me in a different light
more than friends, dare I might
A second passes, an eternity for me
is this the theory of relativity?
But sad to say, making me tear
in my inertial frame she does leer
She looks about, she turns around,
as if a dirty rat she found
her face contorts, "EWWWW!" she retorts,
Seppukku awaits, I ready my sword
Hiding myself, I start to blush
My face is red, so hot and flushed
It's so over, we're so done
I had slim chance, now I've none
All around me shrieks and screams,
the prof, imagining it's but a dream
His mouth agape
He accepts his fate
Heed my cries, Hear my tale
Beware of such an epic fail
Before the class you must go
In the toilet, to release the flow
Composed by Agastya and Arjun

item.title: Accounting
item.description:
The sales or revenue is also called the top line of a company
Important Accounting merely means recounting; and this process involves recording, classifying and summarizing of past events and transactions of financial nature with a view to enabling the user of accounts to interpret the resulting summary
Quote “This planet has—or rather had—a problem, which was this: most of the people living on it were unhappy for pretty much of the time. Many solutions were suggested for this problem, but most of these were largely concerned with the movement of small green pieces of paper, which was odd because on the whole it wasn't the small green pieces of paper that were unhappy.” — Douglas Adams


Inflow - Income (money coming in that isn't repayable), Debt/Liabilities (money coming in that is repayable), Selling Asset
Outflow - Expense (Something you're spending money on that you are getting the rewards of instantly, you don't get the money back), Assets (Something you're spending money on that you will get rewards of in long term and you get the money back - recoverable, whatever a firm holds and uses for a long period), Clearing Liability
Classification of transactions happens in these 6 areas ^
Income - Not repayable inflow
Liability - Repayable inflow
Expense - Not recoverable outflow
Assets - Recoverable in the future
Profit and loss is , P&L account deals with revenue
Balance sheet is in liabilities and assets, BL sheet deals with capital
To account for asset usage, depreciation cost is kept in expenses
Depreciation is a non cash expense


Tangible - Land, plant, machinery, etc.
Intangible - Goodwill, etc.
Whatever is payable is a liability, whatever is receivable is an asset
Whatever you use for a long period of time is also an asset


You buy a machine and depreciate it to 0 over 5 years in the machinery account, when you sell it, you log it as: income
If the machine breaks down before depreciation makes it 0, you file the rest as expense


Is an earning as a result of normal business activity or otherwise. It is also called sales turnover
Whatever is from the main core of the business is operating income


An expense is an outflow of money in return for a product or service. It is also known as cost


An asset is a resource which has economic usefulness in business operations over several years


A liability is an obligation owed by the business to any external stakeholder
Every transaction has atleast 2 effects in 1 or more of these 4 buckets
HW - ask about the number of accounts
HW - How many accounts would I have?


business owner and business are separate entities

the profits minus dividends are shown as a liability to the owner


each company is an ongoing operation - accounting is to be done with the idea that the company will never close down


Every transaction needs monetary term - no bartering


In the books of accounting, everything is accounted for at historical costs only
No notional or market values


whatever you're earning has to be matched - P&L is accurately depicted - transactions must be accounted for when its coming in


Accounting for things in the right period


you will account for a transaction even if actual cash isn't coming in
If it's coming in then account for it for sure
receivables are accounted for when they are accounted for not when they aren't
Treat every transaction in isolation
receivable account exists brother


anything that is significant enough for decision making should be disclosed separately
If any transaction is above a certain threshold, it has to be shown separately in the reports - the thresholds are set by the companies act
Some classifications have to be disclosed separately even if they aren't above the thresholds set by the companies act
any major event has to be disclosed


there are accounting standards - international, indian, etc.
bunch of rules that tell you how to account for different stuff
Although you are free to choose a standard, stick with it


You cannot record for a notional or forseeable profit but you must record for forseeable losses
Basically if you're happy, stop being happy because accounting doesn't want that
inventory is products unsold by the end of the year - matching principle says what didn't get sold cannot be taken as an expense. inventory is an asset
inventory is to be valued at market value or net realizable value, whichever is lower - exception to cost principle
Todo Prepare your own balance sheet and your own P and L
be




Revenue expenditure is everything that is expense - whatever is used for day to day operations


When the benefits of the expenditure is not exhausted in the year in which it was incurred
An example of expenditures incurred is in purchase of fixed assets
Faq Assets that aren't fixed assets:
Inventory
Short term loans These are called current assets


Proprietor - the person who invests his money in the business and bears all risks connected with the business is called the proprietor
Capital - It means amount invested by the proprietor in the business. For the business, capital is a liability towards the owner.
Drawings - It is the amount of money taken away by the proprietor for personal use


Debtor is someone who owns money to you - usually someone you've sold goods on credit
Other terms for debtor are - receivables, trade receivables, account receivables
Creditor is the person from whom the company has a debt from. Generally the vendor from whom they've bought stuff on credit
Payables, trade payables, accounts payables
Debtor is asset and creditor is liability


Goods - Purchased for resale or to produce finished products which are also meant to be sold
What the company trades or manufactures
Companies can be classified broadly into companies that sell goods and companies that sell services
In goods, companies can be classified into traders and manufacturers
There'll be a purchase account for all the inward movement of goods and a sales account for the outward movement of goods Hint The purchase account is expense, the other effect of purchase is cash (goes down)
The expense account is income and the other effect is cash (goes up) whatever you haven't sold at the end of the accounting period, is called the closing stock, whatever is in closing stock, in the next accounting period, becomes the opening stock "When you're buying, its expense, when you're selling it's sales, jo bachgaya hai, becomes inventory" Inventory isn't a transaction, but since you own it, it's an asset
Returns - Accounted as sales returns, when the customer doesn't like your stuff
Return inward
Return from you - accounted as purchase return, when you don't like your suppliers stuff
Return Outward
Goods which are in the transition stage if the processing time is high is called "work in progress"


Solvent - A person who is in a position to pay his debts as they become due
Insolvent - A person who is not in a position to pay his debts as they become due
When a customer doesn't have enough money to pay their dues, they are declared insolvent, you must write off this asset, call it bad debt. Non performing asset
If, later on the customer gives the money, you account it as an income
Following the principle of conservatism, companies are required to keep a provision for "doubtful" debts


Wages is what is paid to the blue collar staff and salary is what is paid to the white collar staff
Losses are something against which the business receives no benefit
Profit -> Income-Expenses

Say soma starts a tea stall, he brings in 1000 rupees and borrows 1000 rupees. It is borrowed on the condition that at the end of every month he will have to pay 300 rupees. That's all he can borrow at the present Soma starts with 2000 rupees. Total capital employed is 1000 rupees (owner's funds/ shareholders funds) and 1000 rupees of borrowed money (debt/borrowings) Hot plate, vessels, crockery, etc is bought by soma for 1000 rupees. These are fixed assets. Then He buys his raw material like tea, milk, etc. These are his stock/inventory of working capital for 500 rupees. 500 rupees is left On day 1 he sells 100 cups of tea at 5 rupees each. The tradition in the area is that you're paid the next day. Soma hasn't received a single rupee yet but he knows he will receive tomorrow(accounts receivable) He is left with 200 rupees worth of stock which is usable on the next day He has hired a helper wjo will cost him 50 rupees a day. The helpers salary will be paid on a weekly basis. Besides,he has to pay 10 rupees as interest on the loan Soma has not recieved a single penny at the end of day 1, but we know that he generated sales of 500 rupees and material cost was only 300 rupees. In other words,his gross profit was 200 rupees. Sales-direct revenue expenditure = gross profit We are taking into account sales and expenses only without any cash coming in, this is called the accrual principle Consider material cost on day 1. Logically,we take material cost at 300 rupees If soma has to close his business the next day, his fixed assets will barely sell for 200 rupees, so do we take this as a loss of 800 rupees? no cus going converna and all so we gotta keep positive If at the end of the day someone promises you that he will buy 200 cups at 6 rupees, you cant mark that as a profit cus conservatism Copy


Fixed assets- form the productive capacity for any business and are not traded in the course of the business
Current assets - the ones that will get converted into cash within a regular operator cycle
Current liabilities - are liabilities expected to e paid in cash in normal business cycle


Refer to ppt - vishy says its the set of all accounts


Nominal accounts - all accounts related to income or expenses
Real accounts - Anything that can be owned - only fixed assets,stocks and cash- Whatever you can hear see, touch
Personal accounts - personal account, related to an entity, like bank account, customer account, vendor account, loan taken from a bank. They are personal accounts since they represent an entity, they can be assets or liabilities
Jaise sales is nomial account, customer is personal account,
Golden matrix (refer to ppt)
Cash and stock are real and bank and debtors are personal
Liabilities are all personal since they are all related directly to an entity

Quote "Whatever notions you have about debit and credit, please maro CTR+ALT+DELETE"

For personal account, debit the receiver, credit the giver
For real account, debit what comes in, credit what goes out
For nominal account, debit all expenses and losses, credit all incomes and gains Example cash sales - sales and cash accounts. Sales is nominal, cash is real. Sales mein credit, cash mein debit
debit and credit are only accounting operators


STep 1 - identify the accounts affected
STep 2 - for each account, identify the type (real, nominal, personal)
STep 3 - ask the appropriate question based on the type (questions given above) to register it as credit or debit Done Up till here in the presentation
Gross is the value, and net is the gross minus deductions
Gross is usually the higher value and net is the lower value
Eg. net profit = gross profit - taxes, expenses, depreciation
How is the cash discount accounted for?
Accounts quiz 1
A personal account is impacted only when it is an unsettled transaction or it is a settlement of a previously unsettled transaction. The exception to this rule is the bank account, whenever you receive a cheque, it goes straight ot the bank account
Tip Advance is an unsettled transaction, it's like a loan to someone
sundry means miscellaneous


The process of accounting:
Identifying the event
converting the event into monetary terms
recording the journal entry
posting to ledger account - its a place where all the accounts are kept, so that you know whether you're insolvent or not
Preparing the trial balance - this is a quick check of whether your accounts are correct and you can check this using the credit and debit totalling 0. If they don't, you need to fix a few things and adjust some transactions
Preparing the final acounts: Profit and loss account and balance sheet


Usually in a business, transactions that are debited and credited are recorded in a systematic manner and the book in which they are recorded, in a chronological order is called the journal.
The fields that exist in a journal- date, particulars, LF, debit, credit
particulars is the account to be credited or debited and if it's to be debited, it's suffixed by Dr and if it's to be credited, its prefixed by to
After a particular entry is written, a narration must be written for an audit trail
LF- ledger folio, folio means page number.Once an entry is passed, it's posted in a ledger and the page it's posted on is called the LF

The book which contains accounts is called the ledger
Problem Sourabh sent it as a photo on the main group
Important Provision for doubtful debts is from the amount of doubtful debts that didnt become bad debts and they collected on it

To Bad Debts
Add Bad Debts
Add Doubtful Debts
Less Opening Provisions



Note the imbalance in credit and debit - I don't know where I went wrong

item.title: Critical Thinking
item.description:
Not my advice, just stuff my sister, professors and books say
I'd like to keep philosophy out of these notes, but this seems really interesting and important.
This section will be about how to assimilate knowledge and really understand it critically and understand all the little kinks about it



These are "at the heart of critical thinking", to unde
Questions for clarification: clarifying the thinking behind a certain concept - "Why do you say that?", "Could you explain further?", "How does the concentration suddenly reduce on entry of a stream to a CSTR", "Whats the blow off cock there for in a boiler?", "How does the triple product of these partial derivatives equal -1?", "Whats the physical significance of exergy, gibbs free energy, enthalpy,etc"
Questions that probe assumptions - "Why is there no temperature gradient from the boundary layer to the center of the fluid in the pipe?", "Why does entropy always increase?"("just cus")
Questions that probe reasons and evidence - "Could the cold vodka be cause for the antidote not neutralizing the poison?"
Questions about viewpoints and perspectives - "Why don't we use exergy balance here instead of gibbs energy balance?", "Why did maxwell come up with his relations in thermodynamics? What was going on in his mind? Why did he feel the need for it?", "When should I use -this concept- over -that concept-"
Questions about implications and consequences: "If I did exergy balance for this instead of energy balance, what would be different? Isn't it still correct?"
Questions about the question: "What was the point of this question?", "Was that question easy?", "Would we use the concept of entropy in this question?", "How does this question relate to the lecture taken today?"


Basically analyzing, applying standards, discriminating, information seeking, logical reasoning, predicting and transforming knowledge over different situations
These actions aren't too helpful to a student since it's difficult to use this list to develop a critical understanding of a subject. This is probably for teachers to assess students and all


For the theory, ask socratic questions (good ones)
For the questions - ask another question or different calculations for the problem, think of all the ways you could solve the problem incorrectly (and why they're incorrect), think of how to make the problem easier, more difficult or more exciting, make a list of concepts taught in the problem and what the point of the problem was, vary parameters of the questions and study their consequences, try to come up with better ways of solving the problem (more elegant ways - my own addition)

What is the most dangerous thing in ICT?

Quote “Perhaps I'm old and tired, but I always think that the chances of finding out what really is going on are so absurdly remote that the only thing to do is to say hang the sense of it and just keep yourself occupied.”— Douglas Adams, The Restaurant at the End of the Universe
After midems - we're looking at mixtures, so we want to find the entropy, enthalpy, G,etc for mixtures. To find all this, we need to find the pure component property and change due to mixing
There are two parts to this course:

One part for a singular equation to not need mollier diagrams or steam tables
One part for for separation processes
Real Gases

item.title: Environmental Science
item.description:
#Environment
#Environment
Environment good, don't destroy for profit or something
Quote “Anyone who is capable of getting themselves made President should on no account be allowed to do the job.”

Water Pollution
for civilized life you need food, shelter and sustainable infrastructure
NIMBY - not in my backyard Example of environmental science in action China produces 100 million tonnes of methanol a year, they get this from a coal bed, using coal bed methanation (CBM). India uses the synthetic route of using crude oil to make methanol. China is more sustainable? I'm not sure what the example was
Bill and Melinda gate foundation has put up a challenge on how to stop antibiotics from going in common areas outside of the human body and causing resistant bug



people would boil water
mid 19th century filtration began
clogged filters were a big problem
alum was introduced as a water treatment technique in the 18th century and widely used in the 19th century
chlorination became common in the 20th century
Now people are concerned about adverse effects of chlorination, so work into potassium permanganate is being done
Weird fact The concentration in water of oxygen is 7-8 mg per litre for fish. Fish cannot survive in 4 mg per litre.


People would hurl shit out of their windows in absence of a proper sewage system in Paris. I personally suppose this was not because of absence of sewage systems but simply because they were French
Napolean ended up building a sewage system so this maybe stopped


Many cities combine their waste systems and cause pollution this way
Cesspools and vaults were common, carting waste (ew)
Non centralized sewage systems - not successful
Untreated sewage - increases BOD of water and kills the fish, also causes insane amounts of pollution

Ecosystems are composed of interacting living organisms and their physical environment

populations generally maintain a balance state (homeostasis)
there is a dynamic equilibrium which is whats behind homeostasis with stabilizing (for negative feedback) and destabilizing (for positive feedback) effects. This maintains the population in a balanced state
A classic example of predator prey interactions is the hare and lynx relationship

A system of weakness that the incompetent perpetuate so they can fool themselves

Ministry of environment and forestry is the section of Indian government associated with environmental science and engineering
environmental science in these days is very cha ching cha ching. MONEY is BIG. Big projects need such work so they don't fail in the eyes of public and government
anthropological activities - industrial, man made, civilized activities
Cause and effect of anthropological activities need to be weighed
Sustainability is - leaving the planet in a better condition for the next generation Look at online undergraduate competitions. TOMORROW FOR SURE

You need to the the due diligence for the consequences for your project before you start it

EIA report - environmental impact assessment
Prepare one
It's a detailing of all the activities you're proposing to carry out. What all will be included in this? Carbon footprint, emissions, how you're dealing with your waste and emissions, environment management plan, HSE (health, safety and environment), event management plan (if accident happens)
Types of projects - class A (of scale enough to be of national importance), class B1 (little less, get the license from the state government), class B2 (get license from district agency)
No project that comes under this -redacted- if it is any department. No chemical which comes in category 25 - synthetic organic chemicals Important More from less for more

item.title: Fogler
item.description:
A homogeneous reaction is a reaction where all reactants are of the same phase

rate expression is expressed as
the powers of each concentration is usually same as molecularity of that substance in the reaction for elementary reactions
temperature dependency of k is Where E is the activation energy of the reaction, R is the ideal gas constant and T is the temperature in kelvin. A is a factor that represents number of collisions and is also called the frequency factor
As it gets more complicated, just use common sense man.
Series reactions can be modeled by simply taking the each reaction and calculating the rate for every intermediate
Same with parallel


Conversion - always defined on the limiting reagant. In different situations, different elements of the reaction may be limiting and thus choosing it is not possible from just the reaction equation

The symbol for conversion is X


The design equation for a batch reactor
In the following derivation all subscripts refer to the reactant identity and from when the value was provided. N is moles of a substance, X is conversion, r is rate, V is volume

integrate this and get what you want
Batch reactors are pretty obvious really


Unlike batch reactors, the real biggies are the continuous flow reactors that keep taking in chemicals and outputting chemicals continuously
There are two types of flow reactors - plug flow and continuous stir tank reactors(AKA backmix reactors)
The basic equations have symbols F = molar flow rate, C = concentration, V = control volume




This is not differential, just one block. Very simple
All the contents are perfectly mixed at all times (homogeneous). The reaction happens at a concentration lower than inlet.
This reactor is difficult to understand so take a minute to visualize



Also known as a tubular flow reactor

each part of the PFR is perfectly axially mixed but not longitudinally (?) mixed



A homogeneous reaction involves only one phase
The molecularity of a reaction is how many molecules are colliding in a reaction step
for an elementary reaction (only one step), the order of the reaction is the same as it's molecularity
Why is most of this so simple?
Levenspiel explained it in greater depth I feel


We all hate variable volume, such a pointless thing but gotta derive it. :smh: :angryface:
Latorzzz
After this whedon with this easy af chapter

A rough idea of how it goes

item.title: Mixtures
item.description:
#thermo
#thermo


suppose we mix 3kg of water and 1kg of pure H2SO4 at 21.1 C adiabatically, what will the final temperature be?

Info if we actually did this isothermally, we'd have to remove energy since the total enthalpy of the mixture reduces. This is because of hydrogen bonding formed between h2so4 and h20


The above equation can be used for any of the variables like gibbs free energy, entropy, etc


This is a polynomial fitted for delta H mix

x1 and x2 are the mole fractions of the two components Todo Fit a redlich kister expansion to H2SO4


One of the things that separates chemical engineers from the rest of humanity is that we are able to separate stuff.
Distillation, crystallization, liquid liquid extraction, etc.
So we'll have a mixture and a process which outputs a number of pure components
Now if we want to know the minimum work or heat required to separate something, we can use this


Imagine we have a phase equilibrium between a liquid and it's vapour:

I don't know why you should imagine this I just copied this off the board

The above can be written for vapour as well
the derivative of G with respect to components in the mixture is called the chemical potential of that particular component in whichever phase it's in
This is also called the partial molar gibbs energy

An interesting derivation later we see that at equilibrium, the chemical potential of each component in the liquid phase must be equal to the chemical potential of that component in the vapour phase



Last year we had learnt that enthalpy is the addition of enthalpy multiplied by the mole fraction of each component, THIS WAS WRONG
It's the partial molar enthalpy of a component multiplied by it's mole fraction and added up with all the other components - thats the actual enthalpy
Gibbs duhem - get familiar


Now, using the Redlich Kister expansion



N number of ideal gases are being mixed at a certain temperature
Volume change due to mixing is 0,

This means that the partial molar volume is equal to the volume of the pure substance


Problem Suppose we have an isothermal separation like:

Solution


The Partial Molar gibbs free energy of all components has to be the same Problem A problem from the green envelope

Bdababsoia eiasid
The del mix when x tends to 0 also ends up tending to 0

Non ideal mixture -
Mex is the excess property of a real gas Important A reminder for why we are doing all this - we are doing this to get to raoults law, henry's law and solubility



You might notice a pattern here, but that's because you are stupid and actually for quantities like entropy and gibbs free energy and the sort, there is another term after the delta mix to get the excess




Now, using summability relation


Now if we want the partial molar excess property (what a mouthful) at constant temperature, pressure and other components' moles:

Now wat dis look lyk?





The above is for one component. The below is for multiple components

The f_i bar is the fugacity of the component in the mixture, NOT the partial molar fugacity
Pyi is the partial pressure of the gas


=>



At equilibrium:
the above only works for ideal mixtures - like the fi bar related to the pure component fugacity
for the non ideal condition:
the a_i is the activity coefficient
Quote If Prathamesh were normal, his activity coefficient would be 1/88, but since he interacts with 7 people in the class at any point in time, his activity coefficient is 7/88
for vapour phase, IM:
phi is the fugacity coefficient, which is the ratio of fugacity to the actual pressure
since the vapour phase is an IM, it's pressure is low enough and the pressure is equal to the fugacity
the exponent to e is small enough for that part of the equation to be equal to 1
If liquid phase is also an ideal mixture then,
Dis is raoults law
Danger WHAAAA. THIS IS SO OBVIOUS WHY DID WE SPEND LIKE 5 CLASSES PROVING IT? AND NOW WE HAVE A TEST. I HATE THIS LIFE I HATE EVERYTHING AND NOW PROF SAID THAT WE WILL NEVER USE IT




So now all we do is get the enthalpies of all the streams and we assume the mixing process is at steady state. The difference between the in and out enthalpies give you the heat you need to remove from the process
So just mass balance and energy balance

item.title: Utility Network
item.description:
#fluidmech
#fluidmech


Used to increase the contact area between two phases
To increase retention time to ensure reaction completion (more so if the packing is a catalyst)

to have a plug flow in the reactor
In the true sense of laminar flow, a packed bed can never have laminar flow, since it's constantly being disturbed. It is still in laminar flow because of the friction factor curve
packed beds can also be used in drying by passing dry air up wet packing



Darcy showed that average velocity was directly proportional to and inversely proportional to bed thickness
This is expressed as Darcy's law:

The linear relation between flow rate and pressure indicates that the flow is laminar
This is because the reynolds number through the pore spaces is low
Resistance to flow arises mainly from viscous drag:

B is the permeability coefficient. It's completely dependent on the properties of the packed bed
Info In real life, flow isn't always laminar, it can also be turbulent with a high enough head. Many scientists have developed turbulent derived equations
Derivations are a part of the syllabus and will be asked in the examination


specific surface area is just surface area/volume
S_B is the specific surface area of an entire packed bed

assuming only point contact between the particles, . Epsilon is the voidage



These guys tried to derive a general equation for pressure drop across packed beds
They began with getting an analogy between streamline flow in an empty pipe and a packed pipe


If free space between particles is assumed to consist of a series of tortuous channels, the hagen poiseuille equation can be rewritten as:

where K1 is a function of the bed structure, and is a dimensionless constant
Ltube is actually L1 here and is the length of tortuous channel Faq What is a tortuous channel?
randomly formed channels
The length of a tortuous channel will be higher than the actual length of the pipe.
V1 and L1 represent conditions in the pores and are not the same as v_avg and packing length. Both will be higher than their normal values
It is assumed that at any length the length of a tortuous path will be directly proportional to length of a tube
d1 is the equivalent diameter of the tortuous pore space
Kozeny said d1 =

K2 accounts for the proportionality between L1 and Ltube and we can use Ltube since we know only Ltube not L1
180 = k^2*S
Modified friction factor is R/pv^2

R1 is drag force, rho is density and v is v1
for flow to occur, pressure drop is required.
This pressure drop should be exactly equal to the resistance faced by the fluid


The above is a fitted correlation for packed beds by carman
It's similar to the equation proposed by Forchheimer, who suggested that resistance to flow should be considered in two parts:
Viscous force at particle surface
Loss in turbulent eddies and at sudden changes in cross section of channels, therefore

The first term predominates at low flow rates where losses are mainly due to skin friction
Second term predominates at high flow rates and in very thin beds where the enlargement and contraction losses become very important. AT very high flow rates the effects of viscous forces are negligible
For Re < 2, second term = 0, hence

Learn the derivation of the Forchheimer equation
Sawitowski proposed for flow of fluids through hollow packings:

Note the lack of 0.4 on the numerator of the second term
For flow through ring packings, another relation was created (semi empirical):

This is analogous to hejun poisuelle equation
Using 6/S, it transforms to something else
This is not worth remembering and thus I wont write about it here
All these equations will be provided in the exam Important Prof's recommendation - When designing a packed bed column there are softwares that fit a curve on the packed column readings and get you a relation


A fluid cannot be fluidized
Fluidised beds were known only to academicians for many years, until adoption of fluidized catalysts by the petroleum industry
Fluidized beds behave as a single fluid of density equal to that of mixture of solids
It is assumed in fluidized beds that one phase is a solid The danger of saying today Some drunk johnny boy was taking round and met his commanding officer. His commanding officer was sober. Johnny boy wrote in his diary, "today, my commanding officer was not drunk". Think on the danger of this statement


Fluidised catalytic bed reactors
fluidisation - make solids behave as if they were liquid. The upward thrust should be exactly and equal to the downward force

The above graph is the effect of fluid velocity on pressure gradient and delta P
So basically this shows how the friction factor changes with velocity
When fluidisation just starts, its called minimum or incipient fluidisation
The del P per unit length decreases on start of fluidisation since the length increases since the particles move upwards
In fluidization you do not want to carry away the solids.
When a fluid flows slowly upwards through a bed of very fine particles, the flow is streamline and a linear relation exists between the pressure gradient and flow rate
If log(delP/Ltube) is plotted against log(Vavg), a straight line of slope 1 is obtained
In a fluidised bed, total frictional force on particles = effective weight of bed
Thus in a bed of cross sectional area A, depth Ltube, and porosity epsilon, additional pressure drop across bed due to layout weight of particles is given by:

The area cancels out
This relationship applies between the initial expansion of the bed till the transport of the bed

Sheeeeeeeeeeeesh

Discrepancies between calculated and measured velocities are - channeling, electrostatic forces, agglomeration, friction between fluid and walls of the vessels and friction between particles hitting the walls
Channeling results in drag force reducing
Agglomeration - particles come together
Higher the density difference more are the chances of irregularities in the channels


At the point of incipient fluidisation, equations for packed bed flow are applicable.
Take a look at the carman kozeny equation and the packed bed equation

This was derived after substituting the delta P from fluidization in the carman kozeny equation

A value of 3.36 rather than 5 for the carman kozeny constant is used - it matches the experimental data better
minimum fluidisation velocity is given by:
the value of epsilon mf is a function of the size distribution, shape and surface properties of the particles - its the voidage lol
for turbulent flow, use the ergun equation:

dp = diameter of the sphere having the same V/S ratio as the actual particles
substituting the delta P in the above equation:

A particle shape factor is defined as the ratio of the diameter of the sphere with the same volume as the particle having diameter d_p to the particle diameter d_p

item.title: Vapour Liquid Equilibrium
item.description:
#thermo
#thermo
Most of the content relating to this is in mixtures. It's basically the partial molar gibbs free energy must be the same
and gibbs free energy must be the same between the vapour and the liquid
Don't ask. I dont know


Some random rule relating fugacity of a component of a mixture to it's actual fugacity
This is only applicable to ideal mixtures

For real mixtures:

gamma is the activity coefficient
gamma * y_i is the activity
Now we doeth problems

In more than two phases, we have like, lets say c components, so c-1 independent variables (the mole fractions, say) per phase. On top of that T and P are independent variables for single phase so:
total number of independent variables - P(c-1)+2, where P is the number of phases
And number of equilibrium relationships is (P-1)c



This gives degrees of freedom
So like on the saturated lines, with two phases, for a single component, you have 1 degree of freedom and for single phase,single component, you have 2 degrees of freedom as mentioned before in thermodynamics.THIS IS HOW IT CAME ABOUT. Big epik Important After the end semester, it's OK to forget everything in this class.
The only things to remember are the following
